questions.question_text: Summarize the three major radiation mixing (ion-ion collision) mechanisms (also sometimes called ion beam mixing). What are the operative time frames for the different mechanisms? Which mechanism is typically most important for energetic massive ions? What is a typical value for the amount of mixing per dpa (â€œreplacements per atomâ€) for energetic displacement cascade conditions (>10 keV PKAs)?
questions.student_answer:
Recoil Implantation: Within 0.1 picoseconds, the PkAs transfer energy to recoils through collisions, the energized recoils are then implanted into a different part of the material.  This mechanism contributes the least to the variation in mixing, with the area of mixing being limited to < 1 nm^2/dpa.

Cascade Mixing: In about a picosecond, the secondary recoils from the original collisions cause further displacements that "mix" over a larger area.  The process continues until the atoms no longer possess enough energy to cause further displacements.  This mechanism covers an area of about 10 nm^2/dpa.

Thermal Spike: Over a couple picoseconds, the excess energy of the atoms is distributed across the surrounding atoms. The spike in average energy or temperature causes the atoms to diffuse along with the heat gradient.  This mechanism causes the mixing of the largest area at about 100 nm^2/dpa, and it is most important for massive ions.
questions.reference_answer:
8) Three major radiation mixing:

1) RECOIL IMPLANTATION (t ~ 10â»Â¹â´ s) "moving long ways" associated with primary recoil atom events

2) CASCADE MIXING (t ~ 10â»Â¹Â³ s) associated with initial ballistic stage during cascade formation (described by binary collisions)

3) THERMAL SPIKE (t ~ 10â»Â¹Â¹ s) atomic mixing during relatively long cooling period associated with the thermal spike.
=> Dominant mechanisms for typical cascades being 1 order of magnitude larger than other two mechanisms. Mixing per dpa for energetic cascades is ~50 replacements (see OECD report Figures)

Deduct 1 point for missing one of the mixing mechanisms or incorrect time scales.
